rangees.data: Primary restraint to anterior talar translation and internal rotation
Horizontal in neutral position, becomes vertical in plantar flexion

content.subtitle: Subject positioning
text: Supine or seated position
Ankle in slight plantar flexion (15-20°) and internal rotation
Place a small pillow or towel roll under the lateral malleolus for comfort and optimal positioning

content.subtitle: Anatomical landmarks and palpation
text: Locate and palpate the anterior border of the lateral malleolus
Identify the lateral talar neck
The ligament runs between these two points in an anteromedial direction

vues.title: Longitudinal View
positionnement: Place the probe parallel to the ligament's course, from the anterior border of the lateral malleolus to the lateral talar neck
Maintain gentle pressure to ensure good contact while avoiding compression of the ligament
Perform dynamic examination with anterior drawer and inversion stress if indicated

texte: The anterior talofibular ligament appears as a hyperechoic band with parallel fiber orientation, extending from the lateral malleolus to the talus
The lateral malleolus is seen as a curved hyperechoic line with posterior acoustic shadowing
The talus appears as a hyperechoic line with its characteristic curved surface

text: The anterior talofibular ligament (ATFL) is the most commonly injured ligament in lateral ankle sprains. It is a flat, quadrilateral ligament that extends from the anterior border of the lateral malleolus to the lateral aspect of the talar neck.

The ATFL is the weakest of the lateral ankle ligaments and is the first to be injured in an inversion ankle sprain. Its orientation changes significantly with ankle position, becoming more vertical in plantar flexion, which explains its vulnerability during plantar flexion and inversion movements.
The ligament is closely related to the lateral ankle joint capsule and often contains mechanoreceptors important for proprioception and ankle stability.

content.subtitle: Lateral ankle sprain
text: Lateral ankle sprains are among the most common musculoskeletal injuries, with the ATFL being involved in approximately 85% of cases. The mechanism typically involves excessive inversion and plantar flexion.
Ultrasound examination can help grade the severity of the injury:
Grade I: Ligament stretching with minimal fiber disruption
Grade II: Partial tear with some fiber discontinuity
Grade III: Complete rupture with full thickness discontinuity

content.subtitle: Chronic ankle instability
text: Following acute injury, some patients develop chronic ankle instability. Ultrasound can help assess ligament healing and identify potential causes of persistent instability:
- Thickened, hypoechoic appearance suggesting poor healing
- Elongated ligament with laxity on stress testing
- Associated peroneal tendon pathology

content.subtitle: Diagnostic accuracy
text: A 2015 systematic review evaluated different diagnostic methods for lateral ankle ligament injuries. The results for ultrasound were:
Sensitivity: 98.9%
Specificity: 96.2%
These results suggest that ultrasound is a highly accurate and cost-effective method for evaluating ATFL injuries.

content.subtitle: Comparative diagnostic value
text: A comparative study of diagnostic methods for lateral ankle ligament injuries found:
Physical examination < 48h post-injury is less sensitive and has very low specificity
When performed by an experienced evaluator, ultrasound is a preferred modality due to its high sensitivity and specificity (if > 48h post-injury)
While not the best option, physical examination > 48h post-injury, when used alone, remains affordable and reasonably sensitive and specific
